Posts.Content: Thanks for all the info and discussion. I will be seeing the urologist that performed the most recent biopsy, in 2 weeks. We don't have a long history. The following day, I will be seeing a well respected urologist close to where I live. He performed a successful open RP on my brother 15 years ago. I was planning to wait until after my 50th high school graduation reunion in Sept but this is starting to drive me a little nuts; staging the next 5 years of my life, just in case I don't come down for breakfast one morning after that. I think I will be in good hands. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Content: Just got the pathologist report for the biopsy I had last month. I didn't expect PNI involvement but it is what it is. SURGICAL PATHOLOGY REPORT - Final PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS: Prostate, core needle biopsies, twelve: 1. Right apex lateral: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (3+3), involving approximately 30% of the core. 2. Right apex medial: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (3+3), involving approximately 5% of the core. 3. Right mid lateral: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (3+3), involving approximately 5% of the core. - Perineural invasion is present. 4. Right mid medial: - Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (3+3), involving approximately 30% of the core. 5. Right base lateral: - No malignancy identified. 6. Right base medial: - No malignancy identified. 7. Left apex lateral: - No malignancy identified. 8. Left apex medial: - No malignancy identified. 9. Left mid lateral: - No malignancy identified. 10. Left mid medial: - No malignancy identified. 11. Left base lateral: - No malignancy identified. 12. Left base medial: - No malignancy identified. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67

Posts.Content: Maybe I have missed earlier discussions but it doesn't seem enough attention is given to what, if any, life changes are beneficial to guard against possible problems down the road. Burgers and fries might seem a reasonable option for many folks but maybe those of us in this club may want to take a closer look: http://www.naturalhealth365.com/pros...alth-1602.html
Posts.Title: Staying in the Zero Club

Posts.Content: I don't know about kidney stones, Jim. You could be right and if so, I'll deal with that later. But right now, with 4 positive areas for PC on the prostate, I think I'll focus on that first. To answer your question FeatherBoy, I was on active surveillance since 2014. It wasn't a structured program. I was on my own and have no regrets about following that path. Thanks for the question. Does anyone here have a history of robotic surgery at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston? I'm getting ready to get this thing taken care of. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67
Posts.Title: Since 2014

Posts.Content: My urologist phoned me today with the biopsy results from last week. He said it showed 4 positive areas for PC, up from 1 area found in 2014. My last PSA was 3.4. My primary care physician said the DRE I had in 2014 was what found PC initially even though my PSA was in the high normal range. The current biopsy indicated the same Gleason 6 3+3. My uro said he is not immediately concerned and I could remain on active surveillance or opt to have it removed or radiated. He said they could probably spare nerves on one side and possibly more. I have an appointment next month with him. I told him I am not interested in radiation. My prostate size increased in size from 40 to 50s gram. I'm actually fine with this but will probably be joining the prostate removal club and then, hopefully the zero club. I want to avoid the probability of having to catheterize every time I have to urinate as I grow older. My urologist is at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston. I met him once for an evaluation and then the second time when he did the biopsy. So, I dont have a history with this doctor but when asked, he said he has done 500 robotic surgeries. I havent had an opportunity yet to ask how many he has done last week. My main concern is being incontinent. I value any suggestions and any knowledge about robotic surgery at Beth Israel. Age 67 Father, 2 brothers had PC
Posts.Title: Since 2014

Posts.Content: Thanks Jim. I have been taking generic Flomax since 2014. It is becoming less efficient recently possibly due to prostate increased 20% in size in the last few months from 40 to 50 gm. I don't believe urine flow decreased due to PC. My father was diagnosed with PC at about age 80. He took one $1000 pill that gave him hot flashes so he stopped any further treatment. He had to catheterize for the last several years of his life until he was 89. His bladder was fine. One of my brothers had a radicle open prostatectomy 15 years ago. He goes for his last PSA test next month. He has been in the zero club since surgery. My other brother had radiation last year. Seems to be doing ok. This prostate cancer thing is becoming burdensome to me so I am leaning toward robotic removal before the end of the year. I freaked out when first diagnosed in 2014. This Forum helped me enormously. Thanks for your input. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67

Posts.Title: Since 2014

Posts.Content: I had a biopsy in 2014. 1 core positive <<5% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 Active Surveillance Second biopsy 2017. 4 cores positive < 30% Adenocarcinoma. Gleason 6 3+3 So does that mean I'm safe? Seems to me, all currently available treatments are from the caveman era. It's pretty disappointing. And then it seems you have to do a coin flip to choose the doctor that you want to mutilate or burn you. How sick is that. Sorry to be so frank in my opinion. I'm ready to deal with the after effects so I'll be flipping the coin soon. Time to move on to the rest of my life. I'm realizing that I have to develop a sense of humor to trudge through this mess to get to the GOOD SIDE. I guess comedy and tragedy really are two heads of the same coin. PSA 3.3 Dec 2014 DRE revealed hard spot Biopsy revealed <<5% adenocarcinoma in 1 of 12 samples Gleason 6=3+3 Active Surveillance: altered diet to fish/veg PSA 2015 was 2.2 PSA Aug 2016 was 2.7 Active Surveillance: returned to regular diet PSA Feb 2017 was 4.7 (This was tested after DRE) PSA Apr 2017 was 3.4 May 2017 Biopsy revealed: 4 cores positive for Gleason 3+3 disease, relatively low volume (at most 30% involved in each core). Options include continued surveillance vs definitive treatment. Gleason 6=3+3 Age 67
